title: How to Be Green While Saving Green Like the Amish

steps.headline: Repurpose: When we find a new use for an old thing, rather than just throwing it away, we’re keeping it out of a landfill and also cutting costs.
Recycle: If your town has a recycling program, participate!
Hand-Down: Small children don’t stay small for long, so they typically outgrow their clothes before they wear them out so consider reusing them for the next child.
steps.description: Most Amish families have at least half a dozen kids, so they naturally clothe the younger ones with hand-me-downs. If your family is slightly smaller, find other families you can trade with, or at the very least, donate used clothing to charity instead of them hitting the landfill.

steps.headline: Plant a garden and put a dent in your summer grocery bill, reduce your carbon footprint, and make the world a little greener — literally.
steps.description: For example, Craker interviewed Ella Yoder, a fabulously thrifty Amish woman, who among other things uses gallon metal apple butter cans (minus both ends) as seedling protectors in her garden.

steps.headline: Buy from a local farm or farmer’s market if you don’t have a green thumb, but still want to be green.
